docs.lead_paragraph: ACE Ltd., which paid $3.45 billion in cash last year for the Cigna Corporation's property and casualty insurance units, sued Cigna for breach of contract in federal court yesterday, accusing it of misrepresenting the value of the businesses. ACE, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, asserted that after the deal closed, it found over $170 million in ''clear accounting and bookkeeping errors'' in financial statements prepared by Cigna and that Cigna had improperly kept $48 million that should have been refunded to the property and casualty units. A Cigna spokesman did not immediately return a call seeking comment. Cigna, now mainly a health insurer, is based in Philadelphia.

headline.main: AFTER BUYING CIGNA UNITS, ACE SUES FOR CONTRACT BREACH

docs.abstract: ACE Ltd, which paid $3.45 billion in cash last year for Cigna Corp's property and casualty insurance units, sues Cigna for breach of contract; alleges that Cigna misrepresented value of businesses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Few holiday windows are quite so glamorous and popular as those at Saks Fifth Avenue, right across from the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree. This year, in an unusual move, the store based its window story on a new book, ''One Enchanted Christmas,'' put out by a doll company called Little Souls Inc. On the sixth floor, the scrunched-faced dolls that inspired the windows seem to lounge in triumph around the Saks gift area basking in the whispered admiration of shoppers. They are beautiful, of course. They are also expensive. (A Santa with a patchwork velvet cloak and tiny red-rimmed wire spectacles is $680.)

headline.main: This Year The Thought Does Count; It's Not Just a Doll, It's Sort of a, Well, Philanthropic Concept

docs.lead_paragraph: The creators of the Fashion Cafe, an international restaurant chain featuring the world of models and couture, have been indicted on federal charges of conspiracy, fraud and money laundering, the United States attorney's office announced yesterday. One man, Tommaso Buti, 33, was arrested in Milan on Thursday, while his partner and brother, Francesco Buti, 39, remained a fugitive, according to federal prosecutors in Manhattan.

headline.main: Businessmen Who Created Fashion Cafe Are Hit With Fraud Charges

docs.abstract: Tommaso and Francesco Buti, partners in Fashion Cafe chain, are indicted on federal charges of conspiracy, fraud and money laundering; Tommaso Buti is arrested in Milan; brothers are charged with using investors' money for personal expenses and falsely claiming to have invested millions of dollars of their own money in company; two are also charged with defrauding investors in Food Evolution venture, Benetton Sports Cafe and Manhattan office building (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years after the national overhaul of welfare, economists and welfare researchers are questioning some of the conventional wisdom of its shrinking rolls, including the belief that people who got off the rolls were the ones best prepared to work and that the caseload increases that inspired the overhaul were caused by a rising number of single mothers on relief. An analysis of several studies suggests that the women who have been most likely to leave the welfare rolls include many with difficulties, like serious health problems, that make them more likely to be thrown off for violating stricter rules, Robert A. Moffitt, a professor of economics at Johns Hopkins University, said at a recent conference of welfare researchers and economists sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. These women make up a substantial proportion of those who are neither working nor on welfare, Professor Moffitt said.

headline.main: Studies Dispute Some Assumptions on Welfare Overhaul

docs.abstract: Economists and welfare researchers question some of conventional wisdom about shrinking of welfare rolls over last four years, including belief that people who got off rolls were the ones best prepared to work and that caseload increases that inspired overhaul were caused by rising number of single mothers on relief; say it is impossible to tell how much of the shrinking of welfare rolls is due to welfare policies and how mjch to extraordinary economic boom that now shows signs of faltering (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the hot new medical field of laser vision correction, Dr. Jodi Abramson is already a veteran at 33. Three years ago, when she was named medical director of the Montefiore and TLC Laser Eye Centers in White Plains, only 300 doctors around the country were performing the laser eye procedure. Yet Dr. Abramson had already treated thousands of patients, more than any other ophthalmologist in Westchester and Rockland Counties and probably more than any other female eye surgeon in the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: For 20 months, dozens of cafeteria workers at Goldman Sachs met stout resistance in their efforts to form a union. Week after week, the workers and their supporters distributed fliers up and down Wall Street, saying it was unconscionable for them to earn too little to afford health insurance while they catered to the investment bank's employees, many of them millionaires. But last week, the union seeking to represent 180 cafeteria workers at six Goldman Sachs sites signed an accord with the investment bank's food-services contractor, Restaurant Associates. The contractor agreed to let its workers form a union as soon as a majority of them sign cards saying they want to unionize.

headline.main: Union Allowed at Goldman Sachs Cafeterias

docs.lead_paragraph: NEWT, move over. Teddy, you're history. Jim Watt, who's he? The new political fund-raising champion, without peer, is Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton. Every charter member of the vast right-wing conspiracy, not to mention the Republican National Committee, is gearing up to use her name and image to raise money. ''Without a doubt, she is going to be the best fund-raiser the Republican party has had in a generation,'' said Al Mitchler, a G.O.P. direct-mail guru. ''We're going to have six years of hyperbole over her and people are making it up right now. I'm making it up right now. By God, this is a gift.''

headline.main: The Election; The Devil and Political Fund-raising

docs.lead_paragraph: Charlotte Buskey walks to the door of her apartment and calls to her dog, Tag. He obediently comes, eyebrows raised in expectation. Tag, a 2-year-old black Labrador retriever, is her guide dog. She straps a leather harness around his chest. ''C'mon, Tag,'' she says. He leads her to the building's elevator and down to the street, where three days a week the two catch a van that takes them to Lighthouse International, a nonprofit agency on East 59th Street that helps the visually impaired through education, research and advocacy. Mrs. Buskey, 43, is learning to read Braille there. When she and Tag go to class, they leave behind her husband, Willis, 50, who is all but blind himself.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; In a Confusing City, Providing Lifelines And Lessons for the Visually Impaired

docs.abstract: Article on aid to the blind, provided with funds from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers across the country will face double-digit increases in their health care costs starting next month, reflecting the biggest surge in medical inflation since the early 1990's. The increases will show up in larger deductions from paychecks and higher deductibles and payments for care, especially prescription drugs. Employers learned earlier this year that their health care premiums would be increasing between 10 and 30 percent in 2001. Most companies are absorbing the majority of the hefty increases, hoping to retain important employees in a tight labor market, but they are sharing the burden with workers. And at some companies, employees are paying a growing share of the costs.

headline.main: Consumers Across the Nation Are Facing Sharp Increases in Health Care Costs in 2001

docs.lead_paragraph: Beneath a photographic blowup of bloodshot blue eyes, a surgery center in Fort Wayne, Ind., advertises laser procedures, urging people with poor eyesight to enjoy life without contacts or glasses and ''see better, look better, feel better.'' And all for ''$33 a month per eye or $995 per eye.'' Other centers charge more, the newspaper ad says -- from $1,499 an eye to $2,699.

headline.main: Turning Surgery Into a Commodity; Laser Eye Centers Wage an All-Out Price War
